Shaanxi Key Laboratory of Chemical Additives for Industry College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Shaanxi University of Science & Technology Xi'an 710021 China Elevated carbon dioxide levels, a major environmental concern, pose challenges for causing many climate problems. Addressing this, conversion CO2 into valuable chemicals is highly important. In this work, we explore photothermal catalytic CO2 reduction, an attractive approach that combines photocatalysis and thermal catalysis. We developed an enhanced Nd2O3/TiO2 catalyst using the sol-gel method, which significantly improves the efficiency of converting CO2 to CO in the presence of water. This catalyst exhibited a CO production rate of 22 μmol·gcat −1·h−1 at 130 °C, markedly surpassing the performance of sole photocatalysis by 7.3 times. Through systematic characterizations, we discovered that Nd2O3 prevents TiO2’s transition from anatase to rutile, thereby increasing CO2 adsorption and creating more vacancies. The interface between Nd2O3 and TiO2 forms a Z-scheme heterojunction, crucial for the simultaneous reduction of CO2 and oxidation of water. This research introduces a promising catalyst for photothermal CO2 reduction, which also acts as a reducing reagent. The strategic engineering of dual metal oxide interfaces in this catalyst suggests its applicability in a range of photothermal catalytic processes, marking a significant advancement in the field of CO2 utilization. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Photothermal catalysis CO2 Nd2O3/TiO2 catalyst Lanthanide metal Interface Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Heavy reliance on fossil fuels has significantly raised CO2 levels, exacerbating climate issues like global warming and sea level rise [1,2]. In Mar. 2024, CO2 concentrations reached a historic high of over 424 ppm. Catalytic conversion CO2 into commercially valuable chemicals offers dual advantages: reducing atmospheric CO2 and producing key substances like CO [3], CH4 [4], liquid hydrocarbons [5], alcohols [6], and acids [7]. CO, in particular, is vital as a primary material for synthesizing various important chemicals, making CO2-to-CO conversion crucial [1,8–11]. CO2 reduction typically requires extreme conditions like high temperatures and pressures for its high stability [12–16]. Photocatalysis, harnessing solar energy, activates semiconductor catalysts to create electron-hole pairs that facilitate CO2 reduction. Although various photocatalytic systems for CO2 reduction have been developed for room-temperature application, their activity remains low. Moreover, the use of sacrificial agents, such as triethanolamine or ethylene glycol, adds to the cost of the reaction [17,18]. Enhancing photocatalysis efficiency has led to the emergence of photothermal catalysis, merging the advantages of both photo- and thermal catalysis. This method encompasses thermal-assisted photocatalysis (TAPC), photo-assisted thermocatalysis (PATC), and photothermal co-catalysis (PTCC), etc [19–21]. It's widely acknowledged that these combined methods exhibit significantly higher activities compared to individual photo- or thermal catalysis under similar conditions. While significant advancements have been made in the field of photothermal CO2 reduction, particularly with the utilization of water as an economical reducing agent, the quest for highly efficient catalysts remains a pivotal challenge. Among the catalysts explored, such as MgFeO4 [22], CoO-CuO/Ti1Ce3 [23], Cd0.5Zn0.5S/CdIn4S2 [24–27], WQDs/CdIn2S4 [28], Fe5C2 [29], and Ga-Cu/CeO2 [30] have made notable progress. These catalysts, being free of precious metals, offer a promising direction towards cost-effectiveness. However, their application often demands stringent reaction conditions, which poses a significant limitation. On the other hand, catalysts containing noble metals like Ru/HxMoO3-y [31] and AuCu/g-C3N4 [32], despite their high catalytic activity, come with elevated costs due to the precious metals involved. The above details are in Table S1. Therefore, the current challenge in this domain is to develop catalysts that not only avoid the use of expensive noble metals but also operate under milder conditions, thus bridging the gap between cost-effectiveness and operational feasibility [33–35]. TiO2, known for its affordability, non-toxicity, and efficiency, is a widely used photocatalyst. However, its effectiveness is often limited due to poor visible light absorption and photoelectronic response. Numerous methods have been employed to enhance TiO2’s catalytic performance [36–38], such as incorporating foreign elements to create M/TiO2 composites using sol-gel [39], hydrothermal [40], electrospinning [41], and co-precipitation techniques [42]. Additionally, neodymium (Nd) from the lanthanide series, commonly used in Ziegler-Natta catalysts for polymerizing butadiene and other olefins [43], is notable for its unique luminescence owing to its 4f electron configuration which can modify the band structure of semiconductors. This feature makes lanthanides a popular choice for enhancing other active metals in catalysis [44–46]. For instance, lanthanide-modified TiO2 has shown increased photocatalytic activity in degrading rhodamine B (RhB) [42]. In our study, we synthesized a range of Nd-modified TiO2 catalysts, creating an interface between Nd2O3 and TiO2 using a straightforward sol-gel method for photothermal CO2 reduction with water. Notably, the 17-Nd2O3/TiO2 catalyst (with 17% Nd mass loading) exhibited the highest CO production activity, achieving 22 μmol·gcat −1·h−1 at 130 °C. This performance is three times higher than that of the individual TiO2 catalyst and eleven times higher than that of the Nd2O3 catalyst, respectively. Analysis revealed that the enhanced activity is likely due to the formed Nd2O3-TiO2 interface. Nd2O3 enhances CO2 adsorption, facilitating its transfer to TiO2 for conversion to CO. Furthermore, photothermal conditions played a crucial role in the reaction, as confirmed by control experiments indicating a thermal-assisted photocatalysis process. Under thermal (130 °C) and Xe-lamp irradiation, the heterojunction interface between Nd2O3 and TiO2 markedly boosted the separation efficiency of photogenerated electron-hole pairs, thereby enhancing catalytic performance. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials Nd(NO3)3·6H2O (99.5%) was obtained from Adamas (Shanghai), and titanium butoxide (C16H36O4Ti, AR) was supplied by Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. Acetic acid (AR) was provided by Tianjin Kermel Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd., and hydrochloric acid (AR) was purchased from Sinopharm Group Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. CO2 (99.999%), N2 (99.999%), and Ar (99.99%) were purchased by Xi'an Xincheng Nuomin Electrical Equipment Co., Ltd. Other reagents were obtained from commercial sources and applied without further purification. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The Nd2O3/TiO2 catalysts were prepared by a sol-gel method. Taking the 17-Nd2O3/TiO2 catalyst as an example, titanium butoxide (20 mL) was dissolved in ethanol (20 mL) to obtain a homogeneous solution. After that, Nd(NO3)3·6H2O (4 mmol) was dissolved in a mixed solution of H2O (4 mL), ethanol (15 mL), and acetic acid (4 mL) under stirring. The later solution was slowly dropped into the former solution, and then the pH was adjusted to 1-2 with HCl (12 mol/L). After stirring for 1 h, the mixed solution was aged at 40 °C for 24 h to form a gel, which was then dried at 100 °C for 10 h. The obtained solid was grinded into powder and followed by calcination at 800 °C (5 °C/min) for 3 h in a muffle oven. The catalyst was then prepared and stored for use, and denoted as 17-Nd2O3/TiO2. The mass of Nd element loading is 17%, which was tested by ICP-OES (Table S2). Other catalysts such as TiO2, Nd2O3, and Nd2O3/TiO2 with different Nd loadings were prepared by the similar method. 2.3 Catalyst characterization X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on Bruker D8 Advance with Ni-filtered Cu-Kα (λ = 0.154 nm). The working voltage and current were 40 kV and 40 mA, and the scanning 2θ angle was in the range of 20-80°, respectively. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was tested on ESCALAB 250Xi (Thermo Fischer) with an excitation of Al Kα X-ray source (hν = 1486.6 eV). The working voltage was 14.6 kV, and the filament current was 13.5 mA. The binding energies were referenced by the C1s XPS peak at 284.8 eV. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) was used to test the morphology of the samples, which was conducted on FEI Talos F200X. N2 adsorption/desorption and CO2 adsorption isotherms were tested on a Micromeritics ASAP 2460 instrument. Prior to the tests, the samples were degassed at 200 °C for 15 h under vacuum. The specific surface area was obtained according to the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The pore size distribution of the samples were analyzed by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. CO2 temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) tests were carried out on Micromeritics II 2920. Prior to the tests, the sample was treated at 300 °C in He gas (30 mL/min) for 1 h. After cooling to 50 °C, 10 vol% CO2/He was introduced at 30 mL/min and maintained for 60 min. After that, the catalyst was purged with He to remove the residual CO2 and it was heated from 50 to 800 °C. The desorbed CO2 was recorded by a TCD detector. UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectrum was recorded on a Lamda 950 (PerkinElmer) spectrometer with BaSO4 as background in the range of 200 to 800 nm. The i-t, EIS Nyquist, and Mott-Schottky curves were tested on a CS2350H electrochemical workstation (Wuhan Corrtest Instrument Co., Ltd.). Pt mesh and Ag-AgCl were applied as the counter and reference electrodes. All these tests were conducted in a Na2SO4 solution (0.5 mol/L). Typically, the working electrode was prepared as follows. The samples (10 mg) were dispersed in 1 mL of ethanol and 400 μL of naphthol, and the mixture was sonicated for 30 min and then coated on a conductive glass (FTO) (15.08 × 15.08 mm). It was dried at 60 °C over night and then used directly. The photocurrent tests were recorded under irradiation of a 300 W Xe lamp (Beijing China Education Au-light Co., Ltd). 2.4 Photothermal catalytic experiments The photothermal catalytic reduction of CO2 was performed in a 200 mL autoclave equipped with a top quartz window (diameter 40 mm). In a typical reaction, 20 mg of catalyst and 5 mL of deionized water were added into the reactor. After it was sealed, the reactor was treated under vacuum and then charged with CO2. The photothermal reaction was conducted at 130 °C for 1 h under irradiation from a light source of the 300 W Xe lamp. The distance between the catalyst and the lamp was 15 cm. Upon reaction completion, the gas in the reactor was analyzed by a gas chromatograph (GC-9790 II, Fuli) equipped with a methane conversion furnace and an FID detector, and the liquid products were analyzed by 1H NMR. The catalyst was dried at 50 °C under vacuum and used directly in the next run. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Catalyst characterization TEM was employed to examine the catalysts’ morphology, with the findings illustrated in Fig. 1 . The 17-Nd2O3/TiO2 catalyst showcases hexagon-shaped nanoparticles, predominantly ranging from 14-18 nm in size. HRTEM images (Fig. 1b and c) reveal lattice spacings of 0.352, 0.166 and 0.189 nm, corresponding to the anatase TiO2 (101), (211) and (200) planes, respectively. In contrast, a lattice spacing of 0.180 nm matches the Nd2O3 (211) planes. EDS elemental mappings display a uniform distribution of O (green), Ti (red) and Nd (blue) across the material (Fig. 1e–g). The HRTEM images in Figs. 1c and S1 reveal the microstructure of the interface between TiO2 and Nd2O3, showing that Nd3+ does not enter the lattice of TiO2 but exists in the form of Nd2O3 as individual phase on the surface of TiO2 grains or at the interface of TiO2 agglomerated particles. This indicates the interface between these two materials. This heterojunction at the interface greatly enhances CO2 reduction efficiency under photothermal conditions, which will be discussed below. XRD was utilized to identify the crystal phases of the synthesized samples with varying Nd2O3 loadings, as shown in Fig. 2 . The diffraction patterns of all Nd2O3/TiO2 catalysts exhibited the distinct peaks corresponding to rutile TiO2 (JCPDS file No. 21-1272). Notably, an increase in Nd content was observed to coincide with the presence of the anatase phase of TiO2. These findings suggest that the incorporation of Nd2O3 plays a role in inhibiting the phase transition of TiO2 from anatase to rutile [47,48]. Raman spectroscopy was employed to analyze the surface characteristics of the catalysts, with the results depicted in Fig. 3 a. The observed peaks at 144, 448 and 610 cm−1 confirm the presence of rutile phase TiO2 [49]. The broad band at 234 cm−1 is attributed to the significant lattice disorder and multiple scattering levels in rutile [50]. As Nd loading increases, there is a marked increase in the intensity of the peak at 144 cm−1, while the peaks at 448 and 610 cm−1 show a decrease. The anatase TiO2 peaks are noted at 396, 515 and 640 cm−1, reinforcing the notion that Nd2O3 introduction inhibits the phase transition from anatase to rutile in TiO2, aligning with previous studies [51]. Notably, the anatase phase of TiO2, known for its superior photocatalytic activity compared to rutile [52], demonstrated high efficiency in photothermal CO2 reduction when combined with Nd2O3, as substantiated by subsequent catalytic performance tests. The textural characteristics of the samples were assessed through N2 adsorption/desorption analyses. The corresponding isotherm curves, pore size distribution curves, and analytical data are presented in Fig. 3b and Table 1 . Excluding pure TiO2, all samples exhibited a type III isotherm with an H1 hysteresis loop, indicating specific surface characteristics [53]. The low surface areas observed across the samples suggest that variations in catalytic performance are minimally influenced by surface area, thus implying that mass transfer limitations are not critical in the reaction process. Fig. 3c displays the CO2 physical adsorption isotherms for the catalysts. The adsorption curves of the 17-Nd2O3/TiO2 and 10-Nd2O3/TiO2 catalysts exhibit the steepest slopes, revealing their superior CO2 adsorption capacities. This highlights that Nd loading significantly impacts CO2 adsorption. It is worth to note that Fig. 3c displays the CO2 physical adsorption isotherms for the catalysts at 0 °C. To more accuracy assess the CO2 adsorption capacity at reaction temperature, CO2-TPD, i.e., chemical adsorption, were conducted and the results and detailed quantitative analysis are given in Fig. 3d and Table 2 . These profiles can be categorized into two temperature ranges, i.e., 50-300 °C and 300-750 °C, representing weak and strong CO2 adsorption sites, respectively [54]. Despite the CO2 adsorption amount for the 17-Nd2O3/TiO2 catalyst at 130 °C presenting only a slight difference compared to other tested samples, the 17-Nd2O3/TiO2 catalyst demonstrated increased CO2 adsorption peak areas at 400 °C, suggesting strong CO2 adsorption capabilities. This enhanced adsorption capacity is likely a key factor in the exceptional photothermal catalytic CO2 reduction performance of the 17-Nd2O3/TiO2 catalyst. XPS was utilized to analyze the surface properties of the Nd2O3/TiO2 catalysts. Detailed findings, including the Nd 3d, Ti 2p, and O 1s XPS spectra and their quantitative analyses, are presented in Fig. 4 and Table 3 . The fitted Nd peaks exhibit complexity due to the electrostatic interaction between the 3d orbitals and external 4f electrons (Fig. 4a) [55]. The Nd3+ XPS peaks at 982.5 and 1005.0 eV correspond to 3d5/2 and 3d3/2, respectively [56,57]. The 22.5 eV binding energy shift between these peaks aligns with previous findings [58]. Additionally, Nd exhibits a peak at 1010.6 eV, indicative of a shake-up process, and the peak at 979.1 eV is assigned to the O auger peak [59]. The Ti 2p peaks at 458.7 and 464.5 eV are ascribed to Ti4+ 2p1/2 and 2p3/2, while the peak at 459.8 eV represents Ti3+ 2p1/2 (Fig. 4b). The presence of Ti3+ is known to facilitate oxygen vacancy formation [60,61], enhancing CO2 adsorption. In the O 1s XPS spectrum, three distinct peaks at 529.9, 531.5 and 532.5 eV are identified, corresponding to lattice oxygen, oxygen near vacancies, and adsorbed OH species, respectively (Fig. 4c) [62]. A comparison across the tested catalysts reveals that oxygen vacancy content correlates with the Nd loading; higher Nd loading leads to increased oxygen vacancies (Table 3). 3.2 Photothermal catalytic CO2 reduction The efficacy of photothermal CO2 reduction is fundamentally linked to the choice of catalyst and the specific reaction conditions employed. A comparative analysis of photothermal CO2 reduction using water over various catalysts is summarized in Table 4 . Notably, in the absence of any catalyst, no reaction products were detected, underscoring the insufficiency of photothermal conditions alone in catalyzing the reaction (entry 1). Conventional photocatalysts such as pure TiO2 and P25 demonstrated limited activity, yielding only 7 and 10 μmol·gcat −1·h−1 of CO, respectively (entries 2 and 3). Further, the performance of TiO2 catalysts modified with different lanthanides, including Ce, La, Nd, and Sm, was assessed. Here, the 17-La2O3/TiO2 catalyst demonstrated a CO production rate of 17 μmol·gcat −1·h−1, while the 17-Nd2O3/TiO2 catalyst emerged as the most effective, exhibiting a CO production rate of 22 μmol·gcat −1·h−1 (entries 4-7 vs 8). It's noteworthy that no other carbon-containing products, including CH4, methanol (CH3OH), or formic acid (HCOOH), were produced in these reactions, were produced in these reactions, as confirmed by GC and 1H NMR analyses (Figs. S2 and S3). Compared to pure TiO2, catalysts modified with lanthanides like Ce, La, Nd, and Sm showed improved catalytic performance, indicating that these lanthanide metals could indeed enhance the reaction but with different promotion degrees. When the reaction was carried out in Ar atmosphere devoid of CO2, no CO formation occurred, confirming that CO production is directly attributed to CO2. This conclusion was further substantiated by 13CO2 isotope labeling experiments, which yielded 13CO as a product. These results unequivocally demonstrate that CO2 serves as the carbon source for CO generation, as depicted in Fig. S4. Pure Nd2O3 demonstrated a limited ability to produce only 2 μmol·gcat −1·h−1 of CO, suggesting its role as a promoter rather than the primary active site in the reaction. The performance of Nd2O3/TiO2 catalysts varied with different Nd loadings. Notably, as the Nd content was increased to 19% and 24%, a slight decrease in catalytic activity was observed (entries 12 and 13), reinforcing the idea that Nd2O3 is likely a promoter rather than the principal active site for the reaction. The findings indicate that the 17-Nd2O3/TiO2 catalyst exhibited the optimum activity for this reaction. 3.3 Effect of reaction conditions Reaction conditions play a pivotal role in catalytic performance, we investigated the effects of reaction conditions and the results are detailed in Fig. 5 . The temperature impact on catalysis is highlighted in Fig. 5a, demonstrating a pronounced effect. At a modest 30 °C under light irradiation, CO formation was limited to 3 μmol·gcat −1·h−1. This activity increased significantly with temperature increase, reaching 22 μmol·gcat −1·h−1 at 130 °C, markedly surpassing near-room-temperature results. However, upon reaching 150 °C, a slight increase in activity was observed, establishing 130 °C as the optimal reaction temperature. Water, serving as a reducing agent, is integral to the reaction, with its volume impact outlined in Fig. 5b. At 5 mL of water, the formation of CO reaches its peak, suggesting a balance in the reaction. Insufficient water cannot provide enough active H+, while an excess of water may promote the conversion of CO2 to CO3 2−. Consequently, both deficient and excessive water volumes negatively impact the reaction. Fig. 5c reveals the influence of reaction time on CO formation. Extending the reaction time generally enhances the process, yet a marginal decline in CO activity at 13 h suggests potential catalyst deactivation due to prolonged exposure. The reusability of the catalyst was rigorously tested. It demonstrated consistent performance for at least six cycles, with only a minimal decrease in CO formation activity after the third use, highlighting its notable stability (Fig. 5d). Additionally, XRD analysis of the used 17-Nd2O3/TiO2 catalyst revealed a pattern akin to that of the fresh catalyst, suggesting that its bulk phase remained intact (Fig. S5). XPS results further corroborated this, showing virtually identical spectra for the used and fresh 17-Nd2O3/TiO2 catalysts (Fig. S6). Relative to the pristine 17-Nd2O3/TiO2 catalyst, the used catalyst exhibited an increased concentration of oxygen vacancies but a reduced presence of OH species. Despite these variations, the catalyst maintained consistent performance across the first three runs. This indicates that the minor alterations in oxygen species content did not markedly impact its catalytic efficacy. 3.4 Roles of photo and thermal conditions To elucidate the specific contributions of photo and thermal conditions, the catalytic activities achieved with the 17-Nd2O3/TiO2 catalyst under light, heat, and photothermal conditions were analyzed, as shown in Fig. 6 a. CO2 conversion exclusively yielded CO under both pure light and photothermal conditions. Under solely thermal conditions, no detectable products were formed. Pure photocatalysis at ambient temperature resulted in a modest CO production of 3 μmol·gcat −1·h−1. In contrast, under photothermal conditions, the CO production significantly increased to 22 μmol·gcat −1·h−1, which is about 7.3 times higher than that under pure light conditions. The photocatalytic performance is notably hindered by the rapid recombination of photogenerated electron-hole pairs, leading to relatively low activity. However, in photothermal processes, elevated temperatures aid in the diffusion of reactants and products. This facilitates the movement of photoelectrons towards the conduction band (CB) of the semiconductor catalyst, effectively reducing electron-hole recombination and enhancing photoreaction efficiency [63,64]. Unraveling the precise roles of light and thermal conditions in this complex process remains challenging [20]. To further probe the influence of light, control experiments were conducted using electronic trapping agents (Fig. 6b). When AgNO3 or (NH4)2S2O8 were added as electron trappers, a significant reduction in catalyst activity was observed compared to the reaction without additives. These findings underscore the crucial role of photogenerated electrons and holes in the reaction. Given that sole thermal catalysis showed no activity, it's reasonable to infer that the reaction likely proceeds via a thermal-assisted photocatalysis (TAPC) pathway. The type of light significantly influences the reaction, as evidenced by the data in Fig. 6c. Under visible light irradiation (400-780 nm), the rate of CO formation was notably low, suggesting that visible light lacks the energy to excite the catalyst's electrons. Conversely, under UV light (200-400 nm), CO production was limited to 4 μmol·gcat −1·h−1, substantially lower than the activity observed under full-spectrum irradiation. This indicates that full-spectrum irradiation, likely due to the combined effect of wavelength and light intensity, plays a pivotal role in maximizing CO formation efficiency in the reaction. 3.5 Photoelectrochemical properties of the samples To comprehensively investigate the impact of light irradiation on Nd2O3/TiO2 catalysts in photothermal catalytic CO2 reduction, a series of analytical techniques were employed. These included UV-Vis DRS, Mott-Schottky analysis, photoelectronic current measurements, and EIS etc. The outcomes of these assessments are detailed in Fig. 7 . These tests collectively provide insights into the optical properties, electronic properties, charge carrier dynamics, and interfacial charge transfer processes of the catalysts under light irradiation. Using UV-Vis DRS, the light absorption properties of the catalysts were examined under irradiation within the 200-800 nm wavelength range. In Fig. 7a, the absorption edge of pure TiO2 is identified at 418 nm. Compared to TiO2, all Nd2O3/TiO2 catalysts exhibited significantly enhanced absorption in the UV region, likely attributed to the larger ionic radius of Nd3+ compared to Ti4+, which induces deformation in the TiO2 structure [44]. The Kubelka-Munk plots reveal a band gap of 3.05 eV for TiO2 (Fig. 7b), aligning with the 3.04 eV reported in literature [65]. The band gap of the single material Nd2O3 is 3.85 eV. With the incorporation of Nd2O3, the light absorption capabilities of the Nd2O3/TiO2 composite are altered, indicating a modification in the photocatalytic properties of the material due to the addition of Nd2O3. Among the tested catalysts, the photocurrent-time curve of the 17-Nd2O3/TiO2 catalyst registered the highest response (Fig. 7c), indicating its superior efficiency in electron-hole excitation and separation. Additionally, EIS Nyquist plots (Fig. 7d) reveal that the 17-Nd2O3/TiO2 catalyst has the smallest semicircle, suggesting enhanced separation/transfer of photoinduced charge carriers [66]. The Mott-Schottky curve classifies the 17-Nd2O3/TiO2 catalyst as an N-type semiconductor (Fig. S7). 3.6 Catalytic mechanism As previously stated, due to the larger ionic radius of Nd3+ compared to Ti4+, incorporating Nd into the TiO2 catalyst structure tends to induce lattice distortion and create a proliferation of oxygen vacancies. These vacancies, as verified by XPS tests, enhance CO2 adsorption on the catalyst, corroborated by earlier CO2 adsorption experiments. Furthermore, these oxygen vacancies serve as electron trapping centers, effectively impeding the recombination of electron-hole pairs. EPR tests were conducted as depicted in Fig. 8 . Under irradiation from a 300 W Xe lamp for 10 min, the 17-Nd2O3/TiO2 effectively inhibited the recombination of electron-hole pairs. Additionally, after 10 min of light exposure, a significant increase in oxygen vacancies in the 17-Nd2O3/TiO2 was observed, further corroborating the pivotal role of oxygen vacancies. Additionally, thermal conditions help lower the potential barrier for CO2 reduction, thereby facilitating the efficient conversion of CO2 to CO. Concurrently, water undergoes oxidation to produce O2 and H+ at the Nd2O3/TiO2 interface. Derived from the characterization studies, we propose a Z-type heterojunction mechanism for the 17-Nd2O3/TiO2 catalyst in photothermal catalytic CO2 reduction, as illustrated in Fig. 9 . Based on the valence band XPS spectra analysis (Fig. S8) of TiO2 and Nd2O3, we determined the valence band (VB) energies of TiO2 and Nd2O3 to be 2.83 and 2.58 eV. Further, through analysis of previous Tauc plots (Fig. 7b), we calculated the conduction band (CB) energies of TiO2 and Nd2O3 to be -0.22 and -1.27 eV [67–69]. The heterojunction structure formed by TiO2 and Nd2O3, as evidenced by former HRTEM images, facilitates electron transfer. In this heterojunction, electrons from the VB of both TiO2 and Nd2O3 accumulate in the CB of TiO2. Concurrently, holes migrate from the VB of TiO2, which is more positive. These holes on Nd2O3’s VB can oxidize water to O2 and H+, while electrons in TiO2’s CB can reduce CO2. Electrons transition from Nd2O3 to TiO2’s CB, providing reduction sites for CO2. This process effectively embodies a Z-type heterojunction mechanism that facilitates CO2 reduction and water oxidation to O2 and H+. 4 Conclusions In this study, we have developed a Nd2O3/TiO2 catalytic system for photothermal CO2 reduction, employing a sol-gel synthesis method. The 17-Nd2O3/TiO2 photocatalyst, significantly boosted by thermal energy, demonstrated an outstanding capability in CO production, reaching a rate of 22 μmol·gcat −1·h−1 in photothermal CO2 reduction in aqueous media under Xe lamp irradiation. This rate is a substantial 7.3-fold increase over conventional photocatalysis. Detailed characterizations revealed that Nd2O3 plays a crucial role in inhibiting the phase transition from anatase to rutile in TiO2, and it also introduces additional oxygen vacancies, which are instrumental in enhancing CO2 adsorption. Importantly, the Nd2O3-TiO2 interface establishes a synergistic heterojunction, effectively utilizing a Z-scheme mechanism for the efficient reduction of CO2 in water through photothermal processes. This research not only underscores the effectiveness of our photocatalyst in transforming CO2 into CO but also sheds light on the significant role of lanthanides in catalysis, highlighting their potential in environmental applications. coredata.dc:description: Elevated carbon dioxide levels, a major environmental concern, pose challenges for causing many climate problems. Addressing this, conversion CO2 into valuable chemicals is highly important. In this work, we explore photothermal catalytic CO2 reduction, an attractive approach that combines photocatalysis and thermal catalysis. We developed an enhanced Nd2O3/TiO2 catalyst using the sol-gel method, which significantly improves the efficiency of converting CO2 to CO in the presence of water. This catalyst exhibited a CO production rate of 22 μmol·gcat −1·h−1 at 130 °C, markedly surpassing the performance of sole photocatalysis by 7.3 times. Through systematic characterizations, we discovered that Nd2O3 prevents TiO2’s transition from anatase to rutile, thereby increasing CO2 adsorption and creating more vacancies. The interface between Nd2O3 and TiO2 forms a Z-scheme heterojunction, crucial for the simultaneous reduction of CO2 and oxidation of water. This research introduces a promising catalyst for photothermal CO2 reduction, which also acts as a reducing reagent. The strategic engineering of dual metal oxide interfaces in this catalyst suggests its applicability in a range of photothermal catalytic processes, marking a significant advancement in the field of CO2 utilization.
coredata.dc:title: Photothermal-driven CO2 reduction over Nd2O3/TiO2 heterojunction catalysts in aqueous medium
